channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DATAMONGO-1360] Cannot query with JSR310
item.description:
I have a MongoDb document I successfully store using Spring Data MongoDb. It looks like this:

{
 
    "_id" : "1",
 
    "_class" : "SomeClass",
 
    "createdDate" : ISODate("2016-01-16T07:05:45.656Z"),
 
    "lastUpdate" : ISODate("2016-01-16T07:05:45.656Z")
 
}

When I create a custom Criteria query that looks like this:

query.addCriteria(where("createdDate").lte(LocalDateTime.now()));

The resulting MongoDb query looks like this:

{ "createdDate" : { "$lte" : { $java : 2016-01-16T14:36:50.656 } } }

It consequently fails with this message:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: can't serialize class java.time.LocalDateTime
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:299)

It does not fail when I use a java.util.Date in my query even though I have stilled persisted my document with a java.time.LocalDateTime object. The query then looks slightly different like this:

{ "createdDate" : { "$lte" : { "$date" : "2016-01-16T07:35:19.985Z"}}}

I'm hoping there is a way to not have to convert my LocalDateTime objects to Date objects for querying.

Please advise.

Cheers,
Bjorn

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The toString() representation of the Query instance is not really meaningful before it has been passed to a MongoTemplate instance as the latter is responsible to properly convert all members of the query that had been represented via our custom $java syntax before. The reason for that is that the mappings are completely configurable (i.e. need upfront configuration) which is not possible for an API that can be used with the new operator.

Long story short, the toString() output looking slightly off is not a reason to assume things will not work downstream in the first place. I am assuming you have tests failing and the stuff you listed was basically diagnosing, right? Non time-zoned Java 8 date types are supported out of the box so interactions with the MongoTemplate and the repositories abstraction should deliver results as expected.

Can you clarify or provide a test case showing what's not working exactly?

Hi Oliver,

Here's a specific query that fails. Let's assume date createdDate in db and the LocalDateTime.now() are identical. Also note that I am comparing dates directly with "is" instead of my initial example of "lte" here:

LocalDateTime startDate = LocalDateTime.now();
 
where("createdDate").is(startDate);

Fails with:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: can't serialize class java.time.LocalDateTime

at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:299)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:194)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:255)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:208)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:255)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:194)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:255)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:194)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:255)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:194)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder._putObjectField(BasicBSONEncoder.java:255)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:194)
at org.bson.BasicBSONEncoder.putObject(BasicBSONEncoder.java:136)
at com.mongodb.DefaultDBEncoder.writeObject(DefaultDBEncoder.java:36)
at com.mongodb.OutMessage.putObject(OutMessage.java:289)
at com.mongodb.OutMessage.writeQuery(OutMessage.java:211)
at com.mongodb.OutMessage.query(OutMessage.java:86)
at com.mongodb.DBCollectionImpl.find(DBCollectionImpl.java:81)
at com.mongodb.DB.command(DB.java:320)
at com.mongodb.DB.command(DB.java:299)
at com.mongodb.DB.command(DB.java:374)
at com.mongodb.DB.command(DB.java:246)
at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.MongoTemplate$3.doInDB(MongoTemplate.java:389)
at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.MongoTemplate$3.doInDB(MongoTemplate.java:387)
at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.MongoTemplate.execute(MongoTemplate.java:446)
at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.MongoTemplate.executeCommand(MongoTemplate.java:387)
at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.MongoTemplate.geoNear(MongoTemplate.java:636)
at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.MongoTemplate.geoNear(MongoTemplate.java:618)

It does not fail when I convert it to a java.util.Date.

LocalDateTime startDate = LocalDateTime.now();
 
where("createdDate").is(Date.from(startDate.atZone(ZoneId.systemDefault()).toInstant()));

Please let me know if you need anything else.

Cheers,
Bjorn

We're not really getting any further unless you post the code you're actually executing to produce the stack trace. As outlined above, the pure creation of the Criteria is only half the battle as it doesn't include type mapping executed by MongoTemplate (as already outlined above).

Generally speaking JSR-310 support has been introduced with DATAMONGO-1131 and we didn't get any feedback so far that it's fundamentally broken. Still I'd really like to see an executable test case that produces the error for further investigation.
Will do first thing Monday. Let me know if there is anything special you are looking for.

Here are the four Java objects of interest:

@Document
 
@Data
 
@EqualsAndHashCode(callSuper = false)
 
@Log4j2
 
public class AvailableHotelOnMapView extends AbstractDocument {
 
    private BestRate bestRate;
 
}


public class BestRate {
 
    private HotelOnMap hotel;
 
    private List<BestRateDate> dates;
 
}


public class HotelOnMap {
 
    private GeoJsonPoint location;
 
}


public class BestRateDate {
 
    private LocalDateTime date;
 
    private Integer numberOfUnits;
 
    private List<BestRateAmount> amounts;
 
}

Here is the query that is executed. Notice I am converting java.time.LocalDateTime to a java.util.Date here and all my tests pass.

private void filterOnStayDateAndPriceRange(Query query, LocalDateTime startDate, Integer nights, Integer rooms, Integer minRange, Integer maxRange, String currencyCode) {
 
        if (startDate != null && nights != null) {
 
            // create criteria object that checks availability for every night in question
 
            Criteria[] criterion = new Criteria[nights];
 
            for (int i = 0; i < nights; i++) {
 
                criterion[i] = where("bestRate.dates").elemMatch(
 
                        where("date").is(Date.from(startDate.plusDays(i).atZone(ZoneId.systemDefault()).toInstant()))
 
                                .and("numberOfUnits").gte(rooms)
 
                                .and("amounts").elemMatch(
 
                                where("currencyCode").is(currencyCode)
 
                                        .andOperator(
 
                                                where("amount").gte(minRange),
 
                                                where("amount").lte(maxRange)
 
                                        )
 
                        ));
 
            }
 
            Criteria nightsAvailable = new Criteria().andOperator(criterion);
 
 
 
            query.addCriteria(nightsAvailable);
 
        }
 
    }

Here is the code that executes the query:

NearQuery q = NearQuery.near(point).maxDistance(new Distance(maxDistance, Metrics.KILOMETERS));
 
q.query(buildFilterQuery(request));
 
 
 
GeoResults<AvailableHotelOnMapView> result = mongoOperations.geoNear(q, AvailableHotelOnMapView.class);
Thanks Bjorn, that helps a lot. Looks like geoNear(…) is not correctly mapping the Query instance contained in the NearQuery. Should be an easy fix though. Stay tuned.
